# Optimization Pitfalls
> Learnings from racing and coffee brewing

## Introduction

## On Racing

This goal is simple. Your mission is to optimize the time it gets to make one round around a given track, filled with twists, turns, and straightaways. 

### The "Optimal" Racing Line
What this actually does is rely on only the *local problem* to decide on how to optimize the *global problem*. This is exactly what we do for deep learning: we rely on [gradient descent]() to find ourselves a local minima. Maybe if we scoured the entire search space in machine learning, we could find a better solution, but it's unlikely to offer us additional performance gains (because minimizing errors isn't always the same as maximizing performance).

However, the "global" view of the tracks in Formula 1 are already well-known, so why don't we just consider it all the time, for all decision-making?
